rounds.response:
Looking at the position, White’s king has wandered to f4—dangerously far from home—while material is still roughly equal.  
My rooks are already doubled on the c-file, my bishop on b5 restricts his queenside development, and my knight awaits the right moment.  
Target: the white kingside light squares that become weak after the coming pawn break.

I play the forcing breakthrough [c5c4], liquidating the centre and ripping open lines.  
If White takes back (a-pawn×c4), I immediately crash onto c2 with …Rc2+, forking his king; if he plays d3 I’ll follow with …Nd4 and an avalanche of rooks.  

[c5c4]

White’s king, stranded on e5, has limited pawn cover and no safe retreat routes.

After White blocks with …Kxc3 he drops the bishop on b3 and faces …Rc2+ or …Bd3 slamming the door.  
Presently, the simplest is to advance the pawn to its near-queening square, squeezing White with every push.
